snippet: A paper published in the journal Science Advances found that Middle Eastern cities involved in wars or other crises showed fewer pollutants in the air.
abstract: Jos Lelieveld study published in journal Science Advances finds decreasing levels of pollutants are found in air above cities in Middle East that are experiencing civil unrest and humanitarian crises; study measured nitrogen oxides, which are byproduct of burning of fossil fuels and seen as indicator of economic activity; insight that war and civil unrest can dampen an economy is not surprising, but study introduced effective new tool for recognizing effects.
lead_paragraph: A paper published in the journal Science Advances found that Middle Eastern cities involved in wars or other crises showed fewer pollutants in the air.

headline.main: Study Finds Surprising Byproduct of Middle Eastern Conflicts: Cleaner Air
headline.print_headline: A New Tool to Analyze War’s Effect on the Planet
